moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d5: Without e6 being played, this advance is possible.  It puts Black on the defensive immediately, although White also has to pay attention to development.
moves.3... Na5 4. e3 d6: Black neglected to counterpunch in the center, or to create an escape square for the misplaced N.
moves.5. b4 Nc6 6. dxc6 bxc6 7. Bb2 Bf5 8. Be2: Black has a healthy center, but let an important center pawn hang.
moves.10. Nxe5 Bxb4 11. Nxc6 Qd6 12. Nxb4 Qxb4: Black feared that gxf6 runs into Qxd5, but this simply surrenders another piece.
moves.14. Bd4 O-O 15. Nd2: White is now fully developed, but has two extra pieces.
moves.15... c5 16. a3 Qb6 17. Rb1 Qd6 18. Bc3: Taking aggressive action in the center when at a significant disadvantage seems optimistic.
moves.19. exd4 cxd4: Black resigned here, possibly seeing that Bb4 wins more material.
